Crystalline LaCoO3 perovskite as a novel catalyst for glycerol transesterification Deepshree Phadtare a Sharda Kondawar b Anjali Athawale a ⁎ Chandrashekhar Rode b ⁎ a Department of Physical chemistry, Savitribai Phule Pune University, Ganesh Khind Road, Pune, 411007, India Department of Physical chemistry Savitribai Phule Pune University Ganesh Khind Road Pune 411007 India b Chemical Engineering and Process Development Division, CSIR-National Chemical Laboratory, Dr. Homi Bhabha Road, Pashan, Pune, 411008, India Chemical Engineering and Process Development Division CSIR-National Chemical Laboratory Dr. Homi Bhabha Road Pashan, Pune 411008 India ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract LaCoO3 perovskite was synthesized using sol-gel method by nitrate and acetate precursors of La and Co with varying molar ratios of La and Co (1:1, 1:2 and 2:1). This was found to be an unique strategy to obtain highly crystalline LaCoO3 perovskite material without using any chelating agent. The variation of precursors was found to influence their crystallinity however, variation in molar ratio in the range of 0.5–2, did not affect the formation of perovskite framework. The formation of pure perovskite phase (around or >80%) could be achieved by combination of acetate and nitrate precursors while, the combination of acetate- acetate or nitrate- nitrate precursors resulted in low phase purity for the perovskite due to the formation of secondary phases like La2O3 and Co3O4. Very interestingly, such combination of perovskite and pure oxide phases contributed to enhancement of basic sites which catalyzed the glycerol transestrifiaction with DMC (dimethyl carbonate) to GC (glycerol carbonate) and GD (glycidol). Among all the catalysts studied, NAP-2 showed highest efficiency in terms of 98% glycerol conversion and 77% GC and 22% GD selectivities. The highlight of this work is that first step glycerol transesterification with DMC required basic sites of either metal oxide or perovskite but for cascade reaction involving decarboxylation required both metal oxide as well as LaCoO3 perovskite phase. Keywords Sol-gel method LaCoO3perovskite Glycerol carbonate Glycidol 1 Introduction Mixed metal oxides particularly, perovskite with a composition of ABO3 where the A-site ion is usually an alkaline earth or rare earth element and the B site ions could be 3d, 4d or 5d transition metal element (Fig. 1 ) are commonly employed for various applications due to their unique physical and chemical properties [1]. For example, lanthanum cobaltite has wide spread applications such as black pigmentation in dyes due to strong absorption over the whole visible range [2] while, LaMO3 type perovskites are also useful as gas sensors, mainly for sensing of foul smelling gases like H2S, CH3S, (CH3)2S and nitrogen containing compounds up to a ppm level. This is due to their conductive properties as well as their porous nature and electronic transitions occurring in their valence states [3]. They are also employed as good interconnect material (electrode) in Solid Oxide Fuel Cells (SOFCs), due to their important characteristics viz. electronic conductivity (σ), which is determined by B site ion; and ionic conductivity arising from the presence of oxygen vacancies [4]. It can be applicable as technical ceramic material due to its refractory nature, degree of distortion and mobility of oxygen in lattice structure. Most interestingly, the presence of various types of oxygen species like (O2−, O2-, O-), in the perovskite structure makes them attractive materials as catalysts in oxidation reactions [5], e. g. strontium doped lanthanum cobaltite catalyzes the oxidation of CO and hydrocarbons (automotive exhaust gases) to CO2 and reduction of NO to N2 [6,7]. Alami et al. reported that the oxidation reaction over perovskite proceeds via two mechanisms, viz. suprafacial and interfacial in which lattice oxygen and adsorbed oxygen participate, respectively [5]. On the other hand, it can also provide strong basic sites to facilitate the catalytic transesterification of glycerol with dimethyl carbonate (DMC) to form glycerol carbonate. Glycerol carbonate can further undergo decarboxylation to more value added product, glycidol which requires strong basic sites of metal oxide for the adsorption of librated CO2 over the surface of the catalyst. This undergoes reduction to CO and active oxygen species at oxygen vacancies generated in the perovskite material (Scheme 1 ) [8]. In the literature, various preparation methods reported for the synthesis of perovskite oxides involve solid-state reaction, sol-gel, solid-state thermal decomposition, flame hydrolysis, electrochemical oxidation etc [9]. Among these, sol-gel method offers several advantages like homogeneous mixing of the components at the atomic level; a good stoichiometric control and excellent particle size distribution throughout the bulk material. Typically, sol-gel process for the preparation ABO3 type perovskite includes use of variety of chelating agents such as citric acid [10,11], poly-acrylic acid [12], poly-ethylene glycol [13,14], poly vinyl alcohol [15], stearic acid [16], for the formation of homogeneous colloidal suspension (gel) from starting solution of precursor salts. In the present scenario of continuous depletion of fossil fuel and consequent emission of anthropogenic gases like CO2, a great deal of research is being focused to develop an alternative to fossil fuels. In this respect, biodiesel has found great potential to fulfill world’s energy needs to some extent. Nevertheless, each 100 kg of biodiesel produced, approximately 10 kg of glycerol is formed as a co-product [17]. Hence, valorization of glycerol is the most hunted topic for last couple of decades. Equally important is CO2 capture and its sequestration to mitigate the environmental issues. Glycerol carbonate synthesis by transcarbonation with DMC gives opportunity to utilize glycerol as well as indirect catalytic fixation of CO2. Diverse catalytic systems were reported for this transformation which include mixed metal oxides, metal supported and bio- catalysts [18–22]. Currently, commercial production of glycidol is by reacting glycerol with HCl to give chloro derivative (3-chloro- 1,2 propane diol) followed by its ring closure catalyzed by a strong base [23]. Major disadvantages of this route include, multistep synthesis, generation of inorganic wastes leading to much higher cost for recovery of the final product. Hence, it is very important to develop a sustainable process for one pot synthesis of glycidol. Some ionic liquid and mixed metal oxide catalysts were reported for the synthesis of glycidol. The preliminary studies by Gade et al. reported ionic liquid like tetramethylammonium hydroxide for the transesterification of glycerol with DMC and achieving 95% glycerol conversion with 78% GD selectivity [24]. The same research group then reported 1,8-diazabicyclo [5.4.0] undec-7-ene based IL as an efficient catalyst for glycerol transesterification with DMC to obtain 96% glycerol conversion but with selective formation of GC (82%) and glycidol as a byproduct formed with only 18% selectivity [25]. Ionic liquids involving functionalized quaternary ammonium salts are also reported for this transformation giving 91% glycerol conversion with 90% selectivity towards GC [26]. However, the cost of the ionic liquid, its tedious preparation procedure, inability to recover IL, and hence poor recyclability make it almost impractical to use for a large scale synthesis. Mixed oxides of Mg/Zr/Sr in the ratio of 3: 1 : 1 were also employed for this reaction furnishing 96% glycerol conversion along with 40 and 56% GD and GC selectivity, respectively [27]. Cu-based mixed oxide catalyst employed for glycerol transesterification with DMC showed 96% glycerol conversion with 91% yield of GC [28]. Recently, Algoufi et al. reported 30% KF supported over sepolite as the best catalyst for selective synthesis of GD (82%) with almost complete conversion of glycerol by glycerol transesterification with DMC followed by decarboxylation of GC [29]. Our group has recently reported barium mixed with cerium oxide as an excellent catalyst for the glycidol synthesis via glycerol transesterification achieving 98% glycerol conversion with 80% GD selectivity [30]. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report on synthesis of LaCoO3 perovskite by sol-gel method without using any chelating / binding agents. In continuation of our previous work on glycerol carbonylation, the prepared pure LaCoO3 perovskite samples were evaluated for their catalytic performance for glycerol transesterification with DMC to give both glycerol carbonate and glycidol [30]. The most significant finding of this work was that the first step of glycerol transesterification with DMC required basic sites of either metal oxide or perovskite but the next step of decarboxylation to glycidol was catalyzed by synergic effect of metal oxide and LaCoO3 perovskite. The synthesis of lanthanum cobaltite was carried out using two different precursors of lanthanum and cobalt (viz. nitrate and acetate) with varying molar ratios (1:1, 1:2 and 2:1). These were characterized in detail using different techniques like XRD, FTIR, FESEM, HRTEM, EDAX, elemental mapping and CO2-TPD. LaCoO3 nanoparticles as a highly crystalline material with well defined morphology were obtained without using chelating agent. 2 Experimental details Glycerol (98% pure) was purchased from Merck, India. Dimethyl carbonate was purchased from Aldrich Chemicals, Bangalore, India and dimethyl formamide was taken from TCI chemicals, India. All the chemicals were used as received without further purification. Lanthanum nitrate La (NO3)3.6H2O or lanthanum acetate La (CH3COO)3. H2O (SD fine chemicals, India) and cobalt nitrate Co (NO3)2.6H2O (Qualigens, India) or cobalt acetate Co (CH3COO)2. 4H2O (SRL, India) were used as precursors for the synthesis of lanthanum cobaltite perovskite by sol-gel method [31]. Various combinations of precursor salts were done to arrive at pure crystalline perovskite oxide. These precursors were weighed in equimolar amounts (0.001 M) and dissolved in 20 mL double distilled water. Further, it was stirred for 30 min to obtain homogeneous solution at room temperature. The obtained solutions were kept under stirring at 80 °C for 3 h to get semi gel which was further transferred to porcelain or silica crucible to be heated at 80 °C until there was formation of a stable gel (30 min). As synthesized gels were thermally treated in air at 900 °C for 6 h. According to the type of precursor, acetate (A) or nitrate (N) used for either lanthanum or cobalt and porcelain (P) or silica (S) crucible used during the synthesis, the prepared samples were nominated as NAP or NAS, ANP or ANS, NNP or NNS and AAP or AAS, respectively. In case of NAP sample, molar ratio of lanthanum as well as cobalt precursor was varied as 1:2(0.001:0.002 M), 2:1(0.002:0.001 M). According to the molar ratios of La:Co (0.5, 1, 2), catalysts were nominated as NAP-0.5/ NAP-1/ NAP-2 etc. Fig. 2 . displays pictorial illustration of the catalyst preparation. The glycerol transesterification with DMC was carried out in a 50 mL Parr autoclave. In a typical experiment, 2 g of glycerol (21.73 mmol), 5.87 g of DMC (65.21 mmol) and 10 mL of DMF as a solvent were charged to the reactor with 5% weight loading of catalyst with respect to glycerol. The reaction was carried out under 1000 rpm stirring at 120 °C for 90 min. After the reaction, the mixture was cooled and then the catalyst was separated by filtration, washed with DMF and dried at 110 °C and calcined at 650 °C for 3 h. The catalyst was collected for its reuse for the next run. The reaction mixture was analyzed by gas chromatography to monitor the progress of the reaction. The gas chromatograph (Shimatzu 2025) was equipped with HP-FFAP column (30 m length ×0.53 mm ID ˜1 μm film thickness) and a flame ionization detector. The glycerol conversion and product selectivities were calculated by the following expressions: C o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = m o l e s o f g l y c e r o l r e a c t e d i n i t i a l m o l e s o f g l y c e r o l × 100 S e l e c t i v i t y ( % ) = m o l e s o f o n e p r o d u c t ∑ m o l e s o f a l l t h e p r o d u c t s × 100 In order to check the stability of catalyst, hot filtration test was also performed in which the catalyst was removed from the reaction by filtration after 60 min, and the reaction was continued with the filtrate devoid of catalyst up to another 60 min (Fig S7). Powder X-ray diffraction was done on Rigaku-Powder XRD Ultima-IV-X-ray diffractometer instrument. For phase identification and to know the crystallite size of the prepared material. Geometrical morphologies of lanthanum cobaltite perovskite were observed by Field emission Scanning Electron microscopy using FEI-‘Quanta’-450-FEG instrument. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analysis was performed on a Jeol Model JEM 1200 electron microscope operated at an accelerating voltage of 120 kV. A small amount of specimen was coated on copper grid, dried at room temperature before analysis. TPD experiments were also carried out on a Micromeritics-2720 (Chemisoft TPx) instrument. In order to evaluate the basicity of the catalysts, carbon dioxide TPD measurements were carried out by: (i) pre-treating the samples from room temperature to 200 °C under helium flow rate of 25 mL min−1, (ii) adsorption of carbon dioxide at 40 °C and (iii) desorption of carbon dioxide with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 starting from the adsorption temperature to 750 °C. 3 Results and discussion The values of specific surface area, pore diameter, pore volume and crystallite sizes are shown in Table 1 . All the samples prepared by sol-gel method by varying the precursors, exhibited the specific BET- surface area in the range of 1.6 - 7.8 m2/g. The combination of nitrate precursor of La and acetate precursor of Co resulted in giving the lowest surface area of 1.68 and 1.79 m2/g for NAP-1 and NAP-0.5, respectively. Whereas, the reverse combination of acetate precursor of La and nitrate precursor of Co, showed slight enhancement in the surface area in the range of 2.12 to 4.22 m2/g, with increasing molar ratio of La: Co. Exceptionally, nitrate -acetate combination in case of NAP-2 showed highest surface area of about 7.89 m2/g which could lead to higher catalytic activity as discussed later. Adsorption-desorption isotherms of all the prepared samples have shown characteristic hysteresis loop of type IV (as per the IUPAC nomenclature system) which confirmed the mesoporous nature of the sample (Fig. 3 ). The pore diameter of all the samples was found to be in the range of 36–46 Ǻ and their pore volumes were increasing in the order of ANP-1< NAP-0.5< NAP-1< NNP-1< AAP-1< AAS-1< NAP-2. Among all the samples, crystallite size of both the samples, prepared by acetate precursor (AAP-1 and AAS-1) was found to be the highest 0.37, 0.28 Ǻ, respectively. The crystallite size slightly decreased to 0.24 and 0.25 Ǻ for ANP-1and NAP-1 respectively, which were prepared by using the nitrate precursor. When La:Co ratio was changed in case of NAP-2 and NAP-0.5, crystallite size appreciably decreased to 0.16 and 0.15 Ǻ, respectively, which is responsible for its best catalytic performance in glycerol transesterification. The lowest crystallite size of 0.14 Ǻ was exhibited by NNP-1 sample. Wide angle X-ray diffraction patterns of the prepared lanthanum cobaltite shown in Fig. 4 A–C, revealed that all the prepared samples were crystalline with trigonal crystal structure of rhombohedral symmetry, space group R3m (166). The sharp peaks observed at about 2θ = 23.2°,32.8°,33.2°,40.5°,41.3°,47.5°, 53.6°,58.8°,68.8°,69.8° 78.7°,79.5° with hkl values (012), (110), (104), (202), (006), (024), (122), (300), (214), (220), (208), (134), (128), respectively, were corresponding to the LaCoO3 phase [JCPDS card No # 84-0848]. In all the X-ray diffraction patterns, reflections corresponding to Al2O3 and SiO2 were not seen which clearly suggest that there was no any leaching of Al2O3 and SiO2 from the crucible used during thermal preparation of LaCoO3 perovskite. Fig. 4A displays X-ray diffraction patterns for all the perovskite samples prepared in the porcelain crucible, which clearly suggests that the formation of homogeneous LaCoO3 phase took place in all the samples. Nevertheless, variation of precursors affected their crystallinity to some extent. Among all the samples prepared in porcelain crucible, change from acetate to nitrate precursor caused rise in the intensity of peaks at 2θ = 23.2°,32.8°,33.2°,40.5°,41.3°,47.5°, 53.6°,58.8°,68.8°,69.8° 78.7°,79.5°) and in case of NNP-1 (both nitrate precursors), highest crystallinity was observed. In addition, small intensity reflections observed at 2θ = 27.8°, 28.0° with hkl values (002) and (011) were due to traces of La2O3 [JCPDS card no #83-1345] while, those at 2θ = 37.0° with hkl values (311) were due to Co3O4 traces [JCPDS card no #42-1467] which can be clearly seen in the separate wide angle XRD patterns of the respective samples (ESI Figs. S1–S3). As can be seen from Fig. 4B, NAS-1 sample showed the highest crystallinity and phase purity among all the samples prepared in silica crucible. All other precursor combinations showed formation of LaCoO3 perovskite phase along with presence of small traces of lanthanum and cobalt oxides. XRD patterns of the samples with varied molar ratio of La:Co in Fig. 4C confirmed the formation of LaCoO3 phase and the peaks observed were similar to those shown in Fig. 4A and B. This suggests that change in molar ratio in the range of 0.5–2, did not affect the formation of perovskite framework. However, in case of NAP-2, formation of lanthanum oxide was predominantly seen along with LaCoO3 phase, which might be contributing as active basic sites for glycerol transesterification and decarboxylation of GC as discussed in detail later. In case of NAP-0.5 sample, formation of cobalt oxide phase was observed along with LaCoO3 phase. Furthermore, the wide angle XRD of most active NAP-2 fresh and recovered after third recycle is compared in Fig. S4. It was observed that the reflections corresponding to LaCoO3 phase were retained with slight decrease in the peak intensity but reflections corresponding to basic metal oxide La2O3 were found to be totally vanished. Table 2 shows the percentage of all the phases formed in the synthesis of LaCoO3 perovskite material. It was calculated by the equation given below. (1) % P E = I P E I P E + I S E × 100 where, IPE is the intensity of highest intense peak arising from main perovskite phase i.e LaCoO3 (primary phase) and IPE + ISE is the summation of intensity arising from highest intense peak of primary phase and secondary phases (La2O3 and Co3O4) respectively, from the XRD patterns. The calculation of percentage phase purity revealed that pure perovskite phase (around or >80%) formation was found in the samples synthesized by combination of acetate and nitrate precursors, regardless of using porcelain or silica crucible (e.g. ANP -1, NAP -1, ANS -1, NAS -1). However, when the ratio of respective metal precursors was other than 1:1, the extent of oxide phases increased at the cost of perovskite phase e.g. NAP-2 and NAP-0.5. NAP-2 particularly, showed 40% formation of La2O3 phase which might be the reason for its better activity in terms of glycerol conversion and most importantly for glycidol selectivity which requires presence of perovskite as well as basic metal oxide phase. Interestingly, the samples prepared by combination of acetate- acetate or nitrate- nitrate precursors showed considerably low purity of the perovskite phase which was compensated by the formation of secondary phases like La2O3 and Co3O4. Details of phase purity calculations are given in ESI Table S1. Fig. 5 A–C shows the FTIR spectra of all the prepared samples. In all the spectra, absence of vibration bands for precursors and development of vibration bands for oxides confirmed that there was a formation of LaCoO3 perovskite, which was also in good agreement with XRD results as discussed above. The characteristic absorption bands around 424, 550 and 597 cm−1 were assigned to La-O, O-Co-O/ Co-O-Co and Co-O stretching modes of vibration, respectively in LaCoO3. Fig. 5 A and B depict the FTIR spectra of the LaCoO3 synthesized using 1:1 molar ratio of La:Co and calcined in porcelain and silica crucible, respectively. The bands observed in the range of 420 - 430 cm−1 corresponded to La-O stretching frequency. While, the bands observed around 450 - 550 cm−1 corresponded to O-Co-O bending vibration mode. The Co-O stretching vibrations were represented by the bands in the range of 590 - 675 cm-1 (Table 3 ). More interestingly, samples prepared with La:Co ratio of 2:1 and 1:2 (Fig. 5C b) and c)), showed the sharp band for La-O and Co-O stretching mode of vibration at around 420 and 665 cm−1, respectively, confirming the presence of La2O3 phase other than perovskite phase. Thus, the variation in the ratio of precursors does not seem to eliminate the formation of oxides of precursors but results in increase in the fraction of the respective oxides. The broadening and asymmetry of the bands in all the FTIR spectra was due to CoO6 group asymmetry. The reason might be the existence of cobalt in two different oxidation states (Co2+ and Co3+) involving Jahn-Teller distortion of Co3+ along with polarization of Co-O bonds arising due to local distortion of crystalline structure with lower symmetry [32]. Field emission scanning electron micrographs of all the prepared samples (Fig. S5 a–k) are presented in Fig. 6 . LaCoO3 oxides prepared by heating gel in porcelain crucible (Fig. 6 a–d) showed well defined morphology with agglomeration of submicron particles. In case of LaCoO3 perovskite obtained by acetate-acetate (AAP-1) precursors, agglomeration of particles leading to densification of grains was observed (Fig. 6 (a). LaCoO3 perovskite obtained by acetate-nitrate and nitrate- acetate precursors, ANP-1 (Fig. 6 (b) and NAP-1 (Fig. 6 (c) depicted good interconnection among particles due to gridding of fused particles forming a network within the structure with some voids or gaps created during calcination. Formation of voids or gaps were because of exfoliation of the final product while liberating CO2 during calcination at 900 ⁰C. In case of LaCoO3 perovskite synthesized by nitrate-nitrate precursors i.e. NNP (Fig. 6 (d), a distinct morphology consisting of cubes and elongated spherical particles was observed due to increased percentage of oxide phases such as La2O3, Co3O4 which is in accordance with the results obtained by XRD. LaCoO3 oxides prepared by heating the gel in silica crucible showed similar type of surface microstructure as that of samples prepared in porcelain crucible (Fig. 6 e–h). LaCoO3 perovskite prepared from acetate-acetate (AAS) precursors, showed the elongated or dumbbell morphology arising from spherical particles getting fused during the preparation (Fig. 6 (e). LaCoO3 perovskite obtained from acetate-nitrate and nitrate-acetate precursors viz. ANS (Fig. 6 (f) and NAS (Fig. 6 (g), also exhibited similar structures forming a network with some voids or gaps created during calcination. In case of LaCoO3 perovskite synthesized using nitrate-nitrate precursors i.e. NNS (Fig. 6 (h) again, a distinct morphology was observed due to increased percentage of oxide phases such as La2O3, Co3O4. The agglomerates appeared to be dense with relatively larger sized voids. On the other hand, LaCoO3 oxides synthesized with varying molar ratio exhibited relatively smaller particles (Fig. 6 i–j). In case of LaCoO3 (NAP) (Fig. 6 (i) synthesized using 2:1 M ratio of the precursors (La:Co,) fine spherical particles were seen with fewer voids within the structure. The precursor ratio when varied to 1:2 (La:Co) (Fig. 6 (j), relatively smaller spherical particles were observed interconnected with each other resulting in a cage like structure. The chemical composition and elemental mapping of most active sample (NAP-2) analyzed by SEM-EDS in Fig. 7 b–d showed that there was an uniform distribution of oxygen, lanthanum and cobalt. Fig. 7b shows dense and uniform distribution of oxygen with some irregular dim areas all over the sample which indicates the presence of La or Co. Fig. 7 c and d show that La and Co were homogeneously distributed with lots of spaces which might be because of the oxygen atom that satisfies their valencies in LaCoO3, La2O3 and Co3O4. Fig. 7 e presents the elemental percentage of La (0.15%), Co (0.18%) and O (5.92%) which nearly matched with their stoichiometric proportion (LaCoO31:1:3), confirming the formation of perovskite phase. HRTEM micrographs of NAP-2 sample in Fig. 8 exhibits mixed morphologies of elongated rod like, spherical, spheroidal, polygon, cubic and nearly rectangular particles (Fig. 8 a and b). SAED pattern of NAP-2 sample (Fig. 8 c) shows that the exposed planes of (112), (110) and (130) that corresponded to the inter-planar distance of 2.97, 3.83 and 1.56 nm, respectively. Fringe pattern of the sample prepared by nitrate – acetate precursor with La: Co molar ratio of 2 (NAP-2) exhibited d-spacing value of 1.15 nm which was in accordance with XRD data for the (332) plane (Fig. 8 d). The histogram (Fig. 8 e) revealed that the average particle size was in the range of 115 to 125 nm, which was much higher than the crystallite size calculated from XRD. This might be because of the irregular shapes of the particles observed in TEM [33]. Similar observation has been reported for a higher calcination temperature where aggregation of grains leads to the formation of larger particles. As basic sites are known to play an important role in glycerol transesterification as well as in the decarboxylation step, CO2 TPD profiles of the selective samples and distribution of their basic strength are shown in Fig. 9 and Table 4 , respectively. The total CO2 desorbed was found to decrease in the order of NAP-2 > AAP-1> ANP-1> NAP-0.5. CO2 TPD profiles of all the samples showed two main desorption peaks, one in medium (200–400 °C) and high (400–600 °C) temperature ranges. However, in case of AAP-1 and ANP-1 samples, small desorption peaks at low temperature (< 200 °C) range were also observed. While, in case of NNP-1 and NAP-2 three distinct peaks were seen with peak maxima at 363, 495, 664 and 371, 497, 670 °C, respectively. Among all the samples studied, NAP-2 showed highest CO2 desorption in terms of 0.2503 mmol g− 1 of CO2 desorbed. Interestingly, it was observed from Fig. 9 e) that higher amount of CO2 desorbed in the medium temperature range (0.2456 mmol g-1) which suggests presence of highest concentration of medium strength basic sites among all the catalysts studied. It has been well reported that the presence of medium strength basic sites were important for GD formation [30]. Table 5 shows the activity results for the transesterification of glycerol with DMC to glycerol carbonate. AAP-1 sample showed 68% conversion of glycerol with 86% and 10% selectivity to GC and GD, respectively (Table 5 , entry 1). LaCoO3 prepared in silica crucible showed much lower glycerol conversion of only 48% with 92% selectivity to GC (Table 5 , entry 2). Hence further study was done with the catalysts prepared in porcelain crucible. LaCoO3 catalyst prepared using nitrate precursor (ANP (1) led to increase in glycerol conversion to 88% but the selectivity to GC (91%) and GD (7%) was found to be in the same range as that of AAP (1) (Table 5 , entry 3). In order to increase the basicity, LaCoO3 with change in La precursor from acetate to nitrate an enhanced activity in terms of glycerol conversion of 96% with 85% and 14% selectivity to GC and GD, respectively (Table 5 , entry 4), was achieved. With increased ratio of La/Co to 2:1 with precursor combination as NAP, highest catalytic activity in terms of 98% glycerol conversion with 22% GD and 77% GC selectivity (Table 5 , entry 5) was obtained. Highest activity of NAP-2 catalyst could be explained on the basis of structural characterization. As can be seen from the BET surface area measurements, NAP-2 possessed highest surface area of 7.89 m2/g among all the catalysts studied in this work. The formation of highly crystalline LaCoO3 perovskite phase with the lowest crystallite size of 0.16 Ǻ along with the highest (40%) extent of basic La2O3 phase formation (Table 2) were among the major reasons of the highest catalytic activity exhibited by NAP-2. FTIR study also confirmed the formation of La2O3 phase with sharp band at 420 cm−1 for La-O stretching mode of vibration. FESEM study of NAP-2 catalyst showed formation of smaller sized nearly spherical shaped particles, interconnected with each other resulting in cage like structure which might provide easy access to the active sites of catalyst to substrate molecule. Whereas elemental mapping of most active NAP-2 showed, uniform distribution of O, La and Co with elemental percentage nearly matching to their stoichiometric composition as obtained from EDAX which also supports the formation of perovskite phases which is responsible for the better activity. Moreover, total basicity of NAP-2 found to be highest (0.2503 mmol/g) among all the catalyst studied which was obtained from CO2-TPD results. Furthermore, in case of NAP-2 catalyst, presence of perovskite as well as basic metal oxide phase facilitated decarboxylation of GC formed in transesterification of glycerol. Hence, we have arrived at important finding that, the first step of glycerol transesterification with DMC requires basic sites of either metal oxide or perovskite but for the next step of decarboxylation catalyzed by synergic effect of metal oxide and LaCoO3 perovskite as the driving force for the decarboxylation step is the adsorption of CO2 formed on to the basic sites of the catalyst followed by its activation on oxygen vacancies present in perovskite [30]. The reusability of NAP-2 catalyst was studied and the results are presented in Fig. S7. After each run, the catalyst was separated by filtration and washed with water. Then, it was oven dried followed by calcination at 550 °C for 6 h before its use for the next run. The catalyst showed continuous deterioration in catalytic activity finally giving 66% glycerol conversion. This might be due to decrease in active catalytic sites (La2CoO3 and La2O3 phase) which was observed by wide angle XRD of fresh and third time recycled catalyst (Fig. S4 a, b). The selectivity to glycerol carbonate was found to be increased for all three consecutive reuses. On the other hand, hot filtration test confirmed that there was no any leaching of catalyst during the course of reaction (Fig. S8). 4 Conclusions Synthesis of LaCoO3 perovskite material could be successfully achieved by sol-gel method without using any chelating agent. Several samples were prepared by two different precursors of La and Co (nitrate and acetate) with their molar ratios varied as 1:1, 1:2 and 2:1, respectively. All these samples were thoroughly characterized and evaluated for their catalytic performance for one pot synthesis of GD through glycerol transesterification with DMC to GC. Among all the catalysts, NAP-2 catalyst showed highest efficiency in terms of 98% glycerol conversion and 77% and 22% selectivity to GC and GD, respectively. Excellent catalytic performance of NAP-2 could be explained by (i) its surface area highest among those studied in this work (ii) lower crystallite size of 0.16 Ǻ (iii) formation of highly crystalline LaCoO3 perovskite phase along with 40% formation of basic La2O3 phase which significantly contributed to its basicity (0.2503 mmol CO2 desorbed /g) required for this reaction under study. FTIR study also confirmed the formation of La2O3 phase with sharp band at 420 cm−1 for La-O stretching mode of vibration. FESEM study clearly showed that, in case of NAP-2 catalyst formation of smaller sized nearly spherical shaped particles, interconnected with each other resulting in cage like structure which might provide easy access to the active sites of catalyst to substrate molecule. Whereas elemental mapping of most active NAP-2 catalyst showed, uniform distribution of O, La and Co with elemental percentage nearly matching with its stoichiometric composition. The presence of perovskite as well as basic metal oxide phase facilitated decarboxylation of GC formed in transesterification of glycerol to GD. coredata.dc:description: LaCoO3 perovskite was synthesized using sol-gel method by nitrate and acetate precursors of La and Co with varying molar ratios of La and Co (1:1, 1:2 and 2:1). This was found to be an unique strategy to obtain highly crystalline LaCoO3 perovskite material without using any chelating agent. The variation of precursors was found to influence their crystallinity however, variation in molar ratio in the range of 0.5–2, did not affect the formation of perovskite framework. The formation of pure perovskite phase (around or >80%) could be achieved by combination of acetate and nitrate precursors while, the combination of acetate- acetate or nitrate- nitrate precursors resulted in low phase purity for the perovskite due to the formation of secondary phases like La2O3 and Co3O4. Very interestingly, such combination of perovskite and pure oxide phases contributed to enhancement of basic sites which catalyzed the glycerol transestrifiaction with DMC (dimethyl carbonate) to GC (glycerol carbonate) and GD (glycidol). Among all the catalysts studied, NAP-2 showed highest efficiency in terms of 98% glycerol conversion and 77% GC and 22% GD selectivities. The highlight of this work is that first step glycerol transesterification with DMC required basic sites of either metal oxide or perovskite but for cascade reaction involving decarboxylation required both metal oxide as well as LaCoO3 perovskite phase.
